The Bloomberg 2024 Term High Yield and Income Index is a targeted maturity benchmark that measures the performance of USD-denominated, fixed-rate, taxable high yield (which are considered below investment-grade) and BBB-rated corporate bond market maturing between January 1, 2024 and December 15, 2024, inclusive.
Initially, the Underlying Index is completely comprised of taxable, fixed-rate high yield bonds chosen from the High Yield Index. Once the Underlying Index comes within 1.5 years of its maturity date (e.g., June 30, 2023), the Underlying Index will become a composite index, comprised of bonds from the High Yield Index, and, additionally, BBB-rated taxable, fixed-rate corporate bonds chosen from the Corporate Index also maturing between January 1, 2024 and December 15, 2024, inclusive.
In special circumstances, the composite index phase may be triggered early.
30
Index Methodology. The investable universe of the index includes securities within the Bloomberg US Corporate and US High Yield indexes. The Underlying Index will be comprised of high yield bonds, and after certain milestones are reached, BBB-rated bonds from the Corporate Index are introduced.
The Underlying Index will incorporate BBB-rated bonds under the following conditions: (1) in the last 1.5 years but before the last 6 months of the Underlying Index’s term, the Underlying Index will introduce BBB-rated bonds (which are considered investment-grade) as constituent high yield bonds are called, no longer qualify for inclusion (due to, among other factors, sector reclassifications of issuers, changes in the credit rating of bonds included in the Underlying Index or rebalances to maintain issuer limits), or decline in value compared to a reference point set at 1.5 years from the Underlying Index’s term or (2) if, prior to 1.5 years remaining in the Underlying Index, the market value of the Underlying Index declines below $30B, the Underlying Index will add BBB-rated bonds to maintain its $30B index market value minimum.
The securities in the Index are rebalanced on the last calendar day of each month until six months to maturity. In the first six months of the final year of the Underlying Index’s term, any principal and interest paid by index securities are reinvested pro-rata into the remaining bonds in the High Yield Index or Corporate Index, as applicable; during the final six months of the final year, proceeds are not reinvested and are assumed to be held in cash while earning no interest. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis.
Rules for inclusion allow USD-denominated, fixed-rate coupon corporate bonds with a clean price at or above $60 and $250 mm par amount outstanding that mature between January 1st and December 15th (inclusive) in the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. Bonds with a clean price (i.e., the price does not include accrued interest between coupon payments) below $60 are excluded from the Underlying Index and subject to a 3 month lock-out period before they are eligible for inclusion again at rebalance. During the final 1.5 years of the maturity of the index, bonds that fall below $60 at rebalance will be permanently ineligible for the index. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis. The securities in the Underlying Index may carry a coupon that steps-up according to a predetermined schedule (i.e., the interest rate paid on such securities will increase over time). Bonds that convert from fixed to floating rate, including fixed-to-float perpetuals will exit the index one year prior to conversion to floating-rate. The last rebalance date will be on June 30th of the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. The Underlying Index includes securities from a universe of corporate issuers (e.g., industrial, financial institutions, utilities) determined by Bloomberg Index Services Limited that are rated high yield by all three of the rating agencies named below for the high yield component and BBB for the investment grade component. The High Yield Index must have a rating equal to or below Ba1/BB+/BB+ and above CC. The Corporate Index must have a rating of BBB (or equivalent). The middle rating of Moody’s, S&P Global Ratings and Fitch; when a rating from only two agencies is available, the lower is used; when only one agency rates a bond, that rating is used.
Bloomberg 2025 Term High Yield and Income Index
Number of Components: approximately 221
Index Description. The Bloomberg 2025 Term High Yield and Income Index is a targeted maturity benchmark that measures the performance of USD-denominated, fixed-rate, taxable high yield (which are considered below investment-grade) and BBB-rated corporate bond market maturing between January 1, 2025 and December 15, 2025, inclusive.
Initially, the Underlying Index is completely comprised of taxable, fixed-rate high yield bonds chosen from the High Yield Index. Once the Underlying Index comes within 1.5 years of its maturity date (e.g., June 30, 2024), the Underlying Index will become a composite index, comprised of bonds from the High Yield Index, and, additionally, BBB-rated taxable, fixed-rate corporate bonds chosen from the Corporate Index also maturing between January 1, 2025 and December 15, 2025, inclusive.
In special circumstances, the composite index phase may be triggered early.
Index Methodology. The investable universe of the index includes securities within the Bloomberg US Corporate and US High Yield indexes. The Underlying Index will be comprised of high yield bonds, and after certain milestones are reached, BBB-rated bonds from the Corporate Index are introduced.
31
The Underlying Index will incorporate BBB-rated bonds under the following conditions: (1) in the last 1.5 years but before the last 6 months of the Underlying Index’s term, the Underlying Index will introduce BBB-rated bonds (which are considered investment-grade) as constituent high yield bonds are called, no longer qualify for inclusion (due to, among other factors, sector reclassifications of issuers, changes in the credit rating of bonds included in the Underlying Index or rebalances to maintain issuer limits), or decline in value compared to a reference point set at 1.5 years from the Underlying Index’s term or (2) if, prior to 1.5 years remaining in the Underlying Index, the market value of the Underlying Index declines below $30B, the Underlying Index will add BBB-rated bonds to maintain its $30B index market value minimum.
The securities in the Index are rebalanced on the last calendar day of each month until six months to maturity. In the first six months of the final year of the Underlying Index’s term, any principal and interest paid by index securities are reinvested pro-rata into the remaining bonds in the High Yield Index or Corporate Index, as applicable; during the final six months of the final year, proceeds are not reinvested and are assumed to be held in cash while earning no interest. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis.
Rules for inclusion allow USD-denominated, fixed-rate coupon corporate bonds with a clean price at or above $60 and $250 mm par amount outstanding that mature between January 1st and December 15th (inclusive) in the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. Bonds with a clean price (i.e., the price does not include accrued interest between coupon payments) below $60 are excluded from the Underlying Index and subject to a 3 month lock-out period before they are eligible for inclusion again at rebalance. During the final 1.5 years of the maturity of the index, bonds that fall below $60 at rebalance will be permanently ineligible for the index. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis. The securities in the Underlying Index may carry a coupon that steps-up according to a predetermined schedule (i.e., the interest rate paid on such securities will increase over time). Bonds that convert from fixed to floating rate, including fixed-to-float perpetuals will exit the index one year prior to conversion to floating-rate. The last rebalance date will be on June 30th of the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. The Underlying Index includes securities from a universe of corporate issuers (e.g., industrial, financial institutions, utilities) determined by Bloomberg Index Services Limited that are rated high yield by all three of the rating agencies named below for the high yield component and BBB for the investment grade component. Bloomberg 2026 Term High Yield and Income Index
Number of Components: approximately 246
Index Description. The Bloomberg 2026 Term High Yield and Income Index is a targeted maturity benchmark that measures the performance of USD-denominated, fixed-rate, taxable high yield (which are considered below investment-grade) and BBB-rated corporate bond market maturing between January 1, 2026 and December 15, 2026, inclusive.
Initially, the Underlying Index is completely comprised of taxable, fixed-rate high yield bonds chosen from the High Yield Index. Once the Underlying Index comes within 1.5 years of its maturity date (e.g., June 30, 2025), the Underlying Index will become a composite index, comprised of bonds from the High Yield Index, and, additionally, BBB-rated taxable, fixed-rate corporate bonds chosen from the Corporate Index also maturing between January 1, 2026 and December 15, 2026, inclusive.
In special circumstances, the composite index phase may be triggered early.
Index Methodology. The investable universe of the index includes securities within the Bloomberg US Corporate and US High Yield indexes. The Underlying Index will be comprised of high yield bonds, and after certain milestones are reached, BBB-rated bonds from the Corporate Index are introduced.
The Underlying Index will incorporate BBB-rated bonds under the following conditions: (1) in the last 1.5 years but before the last 6 months of the Underlying Index’s term, the Underlying Index will introduce BBB-rated bonds (which are considered investment-grade) as constituent high yield bonds (which are considered below investment-grade) are called, no longer qualify for inclusion (due to, among other factors, sector reclassifications of issuers, changes in the credit rating of bonds included in the Underlying Index or rebalances to maintain issuer limits), or decline in value compared to a reference point set
32
at 1.5 years from the Underlying Index’s term or (2) if, prior to 1.5 years remaining in the Underlying Index, the market value of the Underlying Index declines below $30B, the Underlying Index will add BBB-rated bonds to maintain its $30B index market value minimum.
The securities in the Index are rebalanced on the last calendar day of each month until six months to maturity. In the first six months of the final year of the Underlying Index’s term, any principal and interest paid by index securities are reinvested pro-rata into the remaining bonds in the High Yield Index or Corporate Index, as applicable; during the final six months of the final year, proceeds are not reinvested and are assumed to be held in cash while earning no interest. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis.
Rules for inclusion allow USD-denominated, fixed-rate coupon corporate bonds with a clean price at or above $60 and $250 mm par amount outstanding that mature between January 1st and December 15th (inclusive) in the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. Bonds with a clean price (i.e., the price does not include accrued interest between coupon payments) below $60 are excluded from the Underlying Index and subject to a 3 month lock-out period before they are eligible for inclusion again at rebalance. During the final 1.5 years of the maturity of the index, bonds that fall below $60 at rebalance will be permanently ineligible for the index. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis. The securities in the Underlying Index may carry a coupon that steps-up according to a predetermined schedule (i.e., the interest rate paid on such securities will increase over time). Bonds that convert from fixed to floating rate, including fixed-to-float perpetuals will exit the index one year prior to conversion to floating-rate. The last rebalance date will be on June 30th of the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. The Underlying Index includes securities from a universe of corporate issuers (e.g., industrial, financial institutions, utilities) determined by Bloomberg Index Services Limited that are rated high yield by all three of the rating agencies named below for the high yield component and BBB for the investment grade component. The High Yield Index must have a rating equal to or below Ba1/BB+/BB+ and above CC. The Corporate Index must have a rating of BBB (or equivalent). The middle rating of Moody’s, S&P Global Ratings and Fitch; when a rating from only two agencies is available, the lower is used; when only one agency rates a bond, that rating is used.
Bloomberg 2027 Term High Yield and Income Index
Number of Components: approximately 267
Index Description. The Bloomberg 2027 Term High Yield and Income Index is a targeted maturity benchmark that measures the performance of USD-denominated, fixed-rate, taxable high yield (which are considered below investment-grade and commonly referred to as “junk bonds”) and BBB-rated corporate bond market maturing between January 1, 2027 and December 15, 2027, inclusive.
Initially, the Underlying Index is completely comprised of taxable, fixed-rate high yield bonds chosen from the High Yield Index. Once the Underlying Index comes within 1.5 years of its maturity date (e.g., June 30, 2026), the Underlying Index will become a composite index, comprised of bonds from the High Yield Index, and, additionally, BBB-rated taxable, fixed-rate corporate bonds chosen from the Corporate Index also maturing between January 1, 2027 and December 15, 2027, inclusive.
In special circumstances, the composite index phase may be triggered early.
Index Methodology. The investable universe of the index includes securities within the Bloomberg US Corporate and US High Yield indexes. The Underlying Index will be comprised of high yield bonds, and after certain milestones are reached, BBB-rated bonds from the Corporate Index are introduced.
The Underlying Index will incorporate BBB-rated bonds under the following conditions: (1) in the last 1.5 years but before the last 6 months of the Underlying Index’s term, the Underlying Index will introduce BBB-rated bonds (which are considered investment-grade) as constituent high yield bonds (which are considered below investment-grade) are called, no longer qualify for inclusion (due to, among other factors, sector reclassifications of issuers, changes in the credit rating of bonds included in the Underlying Index or rebalances to maintain issuer limits), or decline in value compared to a reference point set at 1.5 years from the Underlying Index’s term or (2) if, prior to 1.5 years remaining in the Underlying Index, the market value of the Underlying Index declines below $30B, the Underlying Index will add BBB-rated bonds to maintain its $30B index market value minimum.
33
The securities in the Index are rebalanced on the last calendar day of each month until six months to maturity. In the first six months of the final year of the Underlying Index’s term, any principal and interest paid by index securities are reinvested pro-rata into the remaining bonds in the High Yield Index or Corporate Index, as applicable; during the final six months of the final year, proceeds are not reinvested and are assumed to be held in cash while earning no interest. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis.
Rules for inclusion allow USD-denominated, fixed-rate coupon corporate bonds with a clean price at or above $60 and $250 mm par amount outstanding that mature between January 1st and December 15th (inclusive) in the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. Bonds with a clean price (i.e., the price does not include accrued interest between coupon payments) below $60 are excluded from the Underlying Index and subject to a 3 month lock-out period before they are eligible for inclusion again at rebalance. During the final 1.5 years of the maturity of the index, bonds that fall below $60 at rebalance will be permanently ineligible for the index. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis. The securities in the Underlying Index may carry a coupon that steps-up according to a predetermined schedule (i.e., the interest rate paid on such securities will increase over time). Bonds that convert from fixed to floating rate, including fixed-to-float perpetuals will exit the index one year prior to conversion to floating-rate. The last rebalance date will be on June 30th of the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. The Underlying Index includes securities from a universe of corporate issuers (e.g., industrial, financial institutions, utilities) determined by Bloomberg Index Services Limited that are rated high yield by all three of the rating agencies named below for the high yield component and BBB for the investment grade component. The High Yield Index must have a rating equal to or below Ba1/BB+/BB+ and above CC. The Corporate Index must have a rating of BBB (or equivalent). The middle rating of Moody’s, S&P Global Ratings and Fitch; when a rating from only two agencies is available, the lower is used; when only one agency rates a bond, that rating is used.
Bloomberg 2028 Term High Yield and Income Index
Number of Components: approximately 294
Index Description. The Bloomberg 2028 Term High Yield and Income Index is a targeted maturity benchmark that measures the performance of USD-denominated, fixed-rate, taxable high yield (which are considered below investment-grade) and BBB-rated corporate bond market maturing between January 1, 2028 and December 15, 2028, inclusive.
Initially, the Underlying Index is completely comprised of taxable, fixed-rate high yield bonds chosen from the High Yield Index. Once the Underlying Index comes within 1.5 years of its maturity date (e.g., June 30, 2027), the Underlying Index will become a composite index, comprised of bonds from the High Yield Index, and, additionally, BBB-rated taxable, fixed-rate corporate bonds chosen from the Corporate Index also maturing between January 1, 2028 and December 15, 2028, inclusive.
In special circumstances, the composite index phase may be triggered early.
Index Methodology. The investable universe of the index includes securities within the Bloomberg US Corporate and US High Yield indexes. The Underlying Index will be comprised of high yield bonds, and after certain milestones are reached, BBB-rated bonds from the Corporate Index are introduced.
The Underlying Index will incorporate BBB-rated bonds under the following conditions: (1) in the last 1.5 years but before the last 6 months of the Underlying Index’s term, the Underlying Index will introduce BBB-rated bonds (which are considered investment-grade) as constituent high yield bonds (which are considered below investment-grade) are called, no longer qualify for inclusion (due to, among other factors, sector reclassifications of issuers, changes in the credit rating of bonds included in the Underlying Index or rebalances to maintain issuer limits), or decline in value compared to a reference point set at 1.5 years from the Underlying Index’s term or (2) if, prior to 1.5 years remaining in the Underlying Index, the market value of the Underlying Index declines below $30B, the Underlying Index will add BBB-rated bonds to maintain its $30B index market value minimum.
The securities in the Index are rebalanced on the last calendar day of each month until six months to maturity. In the first six months of the final year of the Underlying Index’s term, any principal and interest paid by index securities are reinvested pro-rata into the remaining bonds in the High Yield Index or Corporate Index, as applicable; during the final six months of the
34
final year, proceeds are not reinvested and are assumed to be held in cash while earning no interest. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis.
Rules for inclusion allow USD-denominated, fixed-rate coupon corporate bonds with a clean price at or above $60 and $250 mm par amount outstanding that mature between January 1st and December 15th (inclusive) in the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. Bonds with a clean price (i.e., the price does not include accrued interest between coupon payments) below $60 are excluded from the Underlying Index and subject to a 3 month lock-out period before they are eligible for inclusion again at rebalance. During the final 1.5 years of the maturity of the index, bonds that fall below $60 at rebalance will be permanently ineligible for the index. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis. The securities in the Underlying Index may carry a coupon that steps-up according to a predetermined schedule (i.e., the interest rate paid on such securities will increase over time). Bonds that convert from fixed to floating rate, including fixed-to-float perpetuals will exit the index one year prior to conversion to floating-rate. The last rebalance date will be on June 30th of the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. The Underlying Index includes securities from a universe of corporate issuers (e.g., industrial, financial institutions, utilities) determined by Bloomberg Index Services Limited that are rated high yield by all three of the rating agencies named below for the high yield component and BBB for the investment grade component. Bloomberg 2029 Term High Yield and Income Index
Number of Components: approximately 344
Index Description. The Bloomberg 2029 Term High Yield and Income Index is a targeted maturity benchmark that measures the performance of USD-denominated, fixed-rate, taxable high yield (which are considered below investment-grade) and BBB-rated corporate bond market maturing between January 1, 2029 and December 15, 2029, inclusive.
Initially, the Underlying Index is completely comprised of taxable, fixed-rate high yield bonds chosen from the High Yield Index. Once the Underlying Index comes within 1.5 years of its maturity date (e.g., June 30, 2028), the Underlying Index will become a composite index, comprised of bonds from the High Yield Index, and, additionally, BBB-rated taxable, fixed-rate corporate bonds chosen from the Corporate Index also maturing between January 1, 2029 and December 15, 2029, inclusive.
In special circumstances, the composite index phase may be triggered early.
Index Methodology. The investable universe of the index includes securities within the Bloomberg US Corporate and US High Yield indexes. The Underlying Index will be comprised of high yield bonds, and after certain milestones are reached, BBB-rated bonds from the Corporate Index are introduced.
The Underlying Index will incorporate BBB-rated bonds under the following conditions: (1) in the last 1.5 years but before the last 6 months of the Underlying Index’s term, the Underlying Index will introduce BBB-rated bonds (which are considered investment-grade) as constituent high yield bonds (which are considered below investment-grade) are called, no longer qualify for inclusion (due to, among other factors, sector reclassifications of issuers, changes in the credit rating of bonds included in the Underlying Index or rebalances to maintain issuer limits), or decline in value compared to a reference point set at 1.5 years from the Underlying Index’s term or (2) if, prior to 1.5 years remaining in the Underlying Index, the market value of the Underlying Index declines below $30B, the Underlying Index will add BBB-rated bonds to maintain its $30B index market value minimum.
The securities in the Index are rebalanced on the last calendar day of each month until six months to maturity. In the first six months of the final year of the Underlying Index’s term, any principal and interest paid by index securities are reinvested pro-rata into the remaining bonds in the High Yield Index or Corporate Index, as applicable; during the final six months of the final year, proceeds are not reinvested and are assumed to be held in cash while earning no interest. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis.
35
Rules for inclusion allow USD-denominated, fixed-rate coupon corporate bonds with a clean price at or above $60 and $250 mm par amount outstanding that mature between January 1st and December 15th (inclusive) in the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. Bonds with a clean price (i.e., the price does not include accrued interest between coupon payments) below $60 are excluded from the Underlying Index and subject to a 3 month lock-out period before they are eligible for inclusion again at rebalance. During the final 1.5 years of the maturity of the index, bonds that fall below $60 at rebalance will be permanently ineligible for the index. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act. The Underlying Index will be subject to issuer limits of 3%, with any excess redistributed among the remaining constituents on a pro-rata basis. The securities in the Underlying Index may carry a coupon that steps-up according to a predetermined schedule (i.e., the interest rate paid on such securities will increase over time). Bonds that convert from fixed to floating rate, including fixed-to-float perpetuals will exit the index one year prior to conversion to floating-rate. The last rebalance date will be on June 30th of the Underlying Index’s stated maturity year. The Underlying Index includes securities from a universe of corporate issuers (e.g., industrial, financial institutions, utilities) determined by Bloomberg Index Services Limited that are rated high yield by all three of the rating agencies named below for the high yield component and BBB for the investment grade component. The High Yield Index must have a rating equal to or below Ba1/BB+/BB+ and above CC. The Corporate Index must have a rating of BBB (or equivalent). The middle rating of Moody’s, S&P Global Ratings and Fitch; when a rating from only two agencies is available, the lower is used; when only one agency rates a bond, that rating is used.
Bloomberg December 2023 Maturity Corporate Index
Number of Components: approximately 483
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2023 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2023, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2023 and December 15, 2023, inclusive.
The Underlying Index includes U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. In addition, to be included in the index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies below must be rated “investment grade” by at least two of the agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of these agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment grade or are excluded from the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. A parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range defined above. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2023. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities which are downgraded below investment grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds which are screened from the parent index due to being within one year to maturity will be added back into the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity.
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. As the Fund approaches its termination date, its holdings of money market or similar funds may increase, causing the Fund to incur the fees and expenses of these funds. By December 15, 2023, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
Bloomberg December 2024 Maturity Corporate Index
36
Number of Components: approximately 554
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2024 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2024, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2024 and December 15, 2024, inclusive.
The Underlying Index includes U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. In addition, to be included in the index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies below must be rated “investment grade” by at least two of the agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of these agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment grade or are excluded from the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. A parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range defined above. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2024. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities which are downgraded below investment grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds which are screened from the parent index due to being within one year to maturity will be added back into the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity.
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. As the Fund approaches its termination date, its holdings of money market or similar funds may increase, causing the Fund to incur the fees and expenses of these funds. By December 15, 2024, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.

Number of Components: approximately 606
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2025 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2025, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2025 and December 15, 2025, inclusive.

The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. In addition, to be included in the index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies below must be rated “investment grade” by at least two of the agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of these agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment grade or are excluded from the Underlying Index.

of the maturity range defined above. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2025. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds which are screened from the parent index due to being within one year to maturity will be added back into the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity.

Bloomberg December 2026 Maturity Corporate Index
Number of Components: approximately 513
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2026 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2026, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2026 and December 15, 2026, inclusive.
The Underlying Index includes U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of corporate bonds issued by companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. In addition, to be included in the index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies below must be rated “investment grade” by at least two of the agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of these agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. When a rating from only one agency is available, that rating is used to determine index eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment grade or are excluded from the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. The parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range defined above. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2026. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities which are downgraded below investment grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds which are screened from the parent index due to being within one year to maturity will be added back into the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity.
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. As the Fund approaches its termination date, its holdings of money market or similar funds may increase, causing the Fund to incur the fees and expenses of these funds. By December 15, 2026, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
Bloomberg December 2027 Maturity Corporate Index
Number of Components: approximately 402
38
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2027 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2027, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2027 and December 15, 2027, inclusive.
The Underlying Index consists of U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. Further, the securities in the Underlying Index must be denominated in U.S. dollars and have a fixed-rate, although they can carry a coupon that steps-up or changes according to a predetermined schedule. In addition, to be included in the Underlying Index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies named below must be rated “investment-grade” by at least two of the three rating agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of the three rating agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment-grade in order to be included in the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. The parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range defined above. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds that mature in 2027 but had been screened out of the parent index due to being within one year of maturity will be added back into the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the Underlying Index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the Underlying Index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2027. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities which are downgraded to below investment-grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period, existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value.
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. As the Fund approaches its termination date, its holdings of money market or similar funds may increase, causing the Fund to incur the fees and expenses of these funds. By December 15, 2027, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
Bloomberg December 2028 Maturity Corporate Index
Number of Components: approximately 397
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2028 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2028, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2028 and December 15, 2028, inclusive.
The Underlying Index consists of U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. Further, the securities in the Underlying Index must be denominated in U.S. dollars and have a fixed-rate, although they can carry a coupon that steps-up or changes according to a predetermined schedule. In addition, to be included in the Underlying Index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies named below must be rated “investment-grade” by at least two of the three rating agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of the three rating agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment-grade in order to be included in the Underlying Index.
39
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. The parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range defined above. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds that mature in 2028 but had been screened out of the parent index due to being within one year of maturity will be added back into the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the Underlying Index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the Underlying Index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2028. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities which are downgraded to below investment-grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period, existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value.
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. As the Fund approaches its termination date, its holdings of money market or similar funds may increase, causing the Fund to incur the fees and expenses of these funds. By December 15, 2028, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
Bloomberg December 2029 Maturity Corporate Index
Number of Components: approximately 347
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2029 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2029, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2029 and December 15, 2029, inclusive.
The Underlying Index consists of U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. Further, the securities in the Underlying Index must be denominated in U.S. dollars and have a fixed-rate, although they can carry a coupon that steps-up or changes according to a predetermined schedule. In addition, to be included in the Underlying Index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies named below must be rated “investment-grade” by at least two of the three rating agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of the three rating agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment-grade in order to be included in the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. The parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range described above. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds that mature in 2029, but had not been eligible for inclusion in the parent index due to being within one year of maturity, will be eligible for inclusion in the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the Underlying Index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the Underlying Index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2029. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities which are downgraded to below investment-grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period, existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value.
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. As the Fund approaches its termination date, its holdings of money market or similar funds may increase, causing the Fund to incur the fees and expenses of these funds. By December 15, 2029, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
40
Bloomberg December 2030 Maturity Corporate Index
Number of Components: approximately 448
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2030 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2030, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2030 and December 15, 2030, inclusive.
The Underlying Index consists of U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. Further, the securities in the Underlying Index must be denominated in U.S. dollars and have a fixed-rate, although they can carry a coupon that steps-up or changes according to a predetermined schedule. In addition, to be included in the Underlying Index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies named below must be rated “investment-grade” by at least two of the three rating agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of the three rating agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment-grade in order to be included in the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. The parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range described above. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds that mature in 2030, but had not been eligible for inclusion in the parent index due to being within one year of maturity, will be eligible for inclusion in the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the Underlying Index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the Underlying Index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until the last rebalance date of June 30, 2030. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities which are downgraded to below investment-grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period, existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value.
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. As the Fund approaches its termination date, its holdings of money market or similar funds may increase, causing the Fund to incur the fees and expenses of these funds. By December 15, 2030, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
Bloomberg December 2031 Maturity Corporate Index
Number of Components: approximately 347
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2031 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2031, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2031 and December 15, 2031, inclusive.
The Underlying Index consists of U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. Further, the securities in the Underlying Index must be denominated in U.S. dollars and have a fixed rate, although they can carry a coupon that steps-up or changes according to a predetermined schedule. In addition, to be included in the Underlying Index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies
41
named below must be rated “investment-grade” by at least two of the three rating agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of the three rating agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment-grade in order to be included in the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. The parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range described above. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds that mature in 2031, but had not been eligible for inclusion in the parent index due to being within one year of maturity, will be eligible for inclusion in the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the Underlying Index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the Underlying Index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until June 30, 2031. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2031. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities that are downgraded to below investment-grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period, existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value.
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. To the extent that the Fund invests in money market or similar funds, it will incur the fees and expenses of such funds. By December 15, 2031, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
Bloomberg December 2032 Maturity Corporate Index
Number of Components: approximately 293
Index Description. The iShares iBonds Dec 2032 Term Corporate ETF is a term fund that will terminate on or about December 15, 2032, at which time it will distribute its remaining net assets to shareholders pursuant to a plan of liquidation. The Underlying Index is composed of U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2032 and December 15, 2032, inclusive.
The Underlying Index consists of U.S. dollar-denominated, investment-grade securities issued by U.S. and non-U.S. corporate issuers that have $300 million or more of outstanding face value at the time of inclusion. The non-U.S. corporate issuers included in the Underlying Index consist primarily of companies domiciled in developed countries. The Fund will invest in non-U.S. issuers to the extent necessary for it to track the Underlying Index. Each bond included in the Underlying Index must be registered with the SEC, have been exempt from registration at issuance, or have been offered pursuant to Rule 144A under the 1933 Act with registration rights. Further, the securities in the Underlying Index must be denominated in U.S. dollars and have a fixed rate, although they can carry a coupon that steps-up or changes according to a predetermined schedule. In addition, to be included in the Underlying Index, securities that are rated by all three of the rating agencies named below must be rated “investment-grade” by at least two of the three rating agencies, which is defined as Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by S&P Global Ratings or Fitch. When ratings from only two of the three rating agencies are available, the lower rating is used to determine eligibility. Securities with a rating from only one of the three ratings agencies must be rated investment-grade in order to be included in the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is constructed with the following methodology. The parent index, the Bloomberg U.S. Corporate Index, representing U.S. dollar-denominated, taxable, investment-grade corporate bonds, is stripped of securities maturing outside of the maturity range described above. During the final two years of the Underlying Index, bonds that mature in 2032, but had not been eligible for inclusion in the parent index due to being within one year of maturity, will be eligible for inclusion in the Underlying Index until such bonds reach maturity. Securities are then market-cap weighted within the Underlying Index, with a 3% cap on any one issuer, and a pro rata distribution of any excess weight across the remaining issuers in the Underlying Index. The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until June 30, 2032. The last rebalance date will be on June 30, 2032. During this final six month period, the Underlying Index will no longer be updated or rebalanced, except to remove securities that are downgraded to below investment-grade per the eligibility criteria described above. Additionally, during this period, existing bond weights will be allowed to float based on changes in market value.
42
When a bond that is included in the Underlying Index matures, its maturity value will be represented in the Underlying Index by cash throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. To the extent that the Fund invests in money market or similar funds, it will incur the fees and expenses of such funds. By December 15, 2032, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
The ICE® Term Maturity US Treasury Indexes
ICE 2023 Maturity US Treasury Index
Number of Components: approximately 51
Index Description. The ICE 2023 Maturity US Treasury Index measures the performance of the U.S. Treasury bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2023 and December 15, 2023, inclusive.
Index Methodology. The Underlying Index consists of publicly-issued U.S. Treasury securities that are scheduled to mature between January 1, 2023 and December 15, 2023, inclusive. Qualifying securities are U.S. Treasury notes and bonds having $1 billion or more of outstanding face value, excluding amounts held by the Federal Reserve System Open Market Account (“SOMA”). In addition, the securities in the Underlying Index must have a fixed coupon schedule and be denominated in U.S. dollars. Excluded from the Underlying Index are inflation-linked securities, Treasury bills, cash management bills, any government agency debt issued with or without a government guarantee and zero-coupon issues that have been stripped from coupon-paying bonds. However, the amounts outstanding of qualifying securities in the Underlying Index are not reduced by any individual components of such securities (i.e., coupon or principal) that have been stripped after inclusion in the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is market value-weighted based on amounts outstanding reduced by amounts held by the Federal Reserve SOMA. Accrued interest is calculated assuming next-day settlement. The Underlying Index is rebalanced on the last calendar day of the month, based on information available up to and including the third business day before the last business day of the month. New issues must settle on or before the following calendar month end rebalancing date in order to qualify for inclusion for such following month (e.g., an issue must settle on or before November 30 in order to be included in the index on October 31). The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. Cash flows from bond payments that are received during the month are retained in the Underlying Index until the end of the month and then are removed as part of the rebalancing. Beginning June 30, 2023, the Underlying Index will not remove interest payments and matured securities at each rebalancing but instead will retain those amounts as a growing cash position throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. To the extent that the Fund invests in money market or similar funds, it will incur the fees and expenses of such funds. By December 15, 2023, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
ICE 2024 Maturity US Treasury Index
Number of Components: approximately 47
Index Description. The ICE 2024 Maturity US Treasury Index measures the performance of the U.S. Treasury bonds scheduled to mature between January 1, 2024 and December 15, 2024, inclusive.
Index Methodology. The Underlying Index consists of publicly-issued U.S. Treasury securities that are scheduled to mature between January 1, 2024 and December 15, 2024, inclusive. Qualifying securities are U.S. Treasury notes and bonds having $1 billion or more of outstanding face value, excluding amounts held by the Federal Reserve SOMA. In addition, the securities in the Underlying Index must have a fixed coupon schedule and be denominated in U.S. dollars. Excluded from the Underlying Index are inflation-linked securities, Treasury bills, cash management bills, any government agency debt issued with or without a government guarantee and zero-coupon issues that have been stripped from coupon-paying bonds. However, the amounts outstanding of qualifying securities in the Underlying Index are not reduced by any individual components of such securities (i.e., coupon or principal) that have been stripped after inclusion in the Underlying Index.
The Underlying Index is market value-weighted based on amounts outstanding reduced by amounts held by the Federal Reserve SOMA. Accrued interest is calculated assuming next-day settlement. The Underlying Index is rebalanced on the last calendar day of the month, based on information available up to and including the third business day before the last business day of the month. New issues must settle on or before the following calendar month end rebalancing date in order to qualify
43
for inclusion for such following month (e.g., an issue must settle on or before November 30 in order to be included in the index on October 31). The securities in the Underlying Index are updated on the last calendar day of each month until six months prior to maturity. Cash flows from bond payments that are received during the month are retained in the Underlying Index until the end of the month and then are removed as part of the rebalancing. Beginning June 30, 2024, the Underlying Index will not remove interest payments and matured securities at each rebalancing but instead will retain those amounts as a growing cash position throughout the remaining life of the Underlying Index. To the extent that the Fund invests in money market or similar funds, it will incur the fees and expenses of such funds. By December 15, 2024, the Underlying Index value will be represented almost entirely by cash as no securities will remain in the Underlying Index.
ICE 2025 Maturity US Treasury Index
Number of Components: approximately 38
